title: Analyzing the potential of Microblogs for spatio-temporal popularity estimation of music artists

author: Markus Schedl, Department of Computational Perception, Johannes Kepler University

segmentation: Well, good morning everybody would like to present you preliminary results of study.

Actually, we carried out to analyze whether microblogging activity can be used to predict which music artists are popular in which countries, and, well, it's actually my first work on microblog mining.
So my basic area of.
Expertise is music information retrieval and this kind of a motivation.
I tried first to give you some typical applications where music information retrieval is important, so maybe well, some of you are aware of last of M. Who knows last FM.
Well, actually the majority not so actually what they do is analyze your music listening activities and create a personalized web radio stream based on the user model.

Here you can find our intelligent iPod where we use content based feature extraction and analysis to create a large cyclic playlist and the basic idea is to offer this user interface or to offer more intuitive way to.
Browse music collections or.
All about transcending the basic hierarchy.
Oracle organization structure usually have you know.
So ordering by artist name, album name, track name.
So that's actually looking into the audio signal and derive or written based features as well as.
Tumblr based features and then create create an automatic playlist.
And here is a so called Neptune user Interface which combines content based information extracted from music collection with context based term weights extract from web pages about music artists.
So then again calculate some similarities, perform clustering and offer the user a nice way to explore his or her user collection by flying through this virtual landscape.
So it's just a little bit.

Of course, we want to take into account which artists are popular within a particular country, and for a particular point in time.
Now you might say, OK, this is well, not really interesting 'cause we have traditional music charts.
They already exist, such as the Billboard Hot 100.
But the problem with such charts is that they will suffer from some.
Drop X, which I tried to summarize on the next slide.

First of all, such traditional traditional music charts issued by the music industry are not available for all countries of the world, or even if there are available or you want to get access so they won't be made publicly accessible.
Second thing is that usually they cover only particular channels of music distribution, so usually they were based on record sales well sometimes also on digital online sales.
Sometimes they are based on their place.
So on radio station playlists.
But what they never take into account of course is this well large segment of peer to peer file sharing activity and.
Well, you like listening activities.

Well, and the final problem is that well, even if we have music charts for particular country, so you cannot directly compare them between the countries 'cause it might be that in one country only record sales figures are used in other country.
A broader spectrum of different distribution channels are used.
So why not just look into micro block or activity to derive a measure for?
Well, coming up with an estimate of which artists are popular in the respective.
Countries.

So well to say this is rather preliminary work, but the basic research questions were two were interested in the first extend this we wanted to analyze to which extent users use micro block to communicate music listening activity and we want to analyze of course.
Are there any differences between individual countries in this music listening activity on Twitter and well as already mentioned?
The aim is to derive a spatial, temporal musical artist popularity measure from tweets.
Well, here is for the data acquisition we first extracted from world class at tier a list of economic relations around the world.
So we extracted each city of the world with more than half a million inhabitants, which were 790, and also she located them.
So actually we end up with quadruples of City name, country name and longitude and latitude values.

Well, then, assuming that now playing hashtag is used very frequently to communicate music listening activities, we use Twitter's API, or more precisely the Geo Aware search facility offered by Twitters API to search at The xx positions around each of the cities.
And in addition in a radius around the cities of in a radius of 50 kilometers around the city center's position.

Overall cities within the country since we're interested in the distribution on the country level, then we throw all of this data into Lucene index and used as term list for for creating the index.
We used a list of artist names which we extracted from last FM, but well as you might know, the date and last FM is pretty noisy, so we actually matched the artist names from last FM.
With the database of All Music Guide, which is an expert based system on expert based music information system.
So we actually used this list of artist names to index the tweets and then derive just term frequencies from the Lucene index.
Which would then use to predict the popularity often artist in a particular country.
Well, we run our crawlers for five consecutive months between May and September 2.
In 10.

Which extent in which countries with us used to communicate music listening activities.
We first analyzed the total so the absolute number of tweets are within each country.

South Korea Venezuela.
Well done Netherlands first European country, India, Germany and the United Kingdom.
So that's actually about music listening related active.
So what we wanted to assess next is whether this corresponds with general or tweeting activity.

Of the study took into account not exactly the very same time of our of our crawls.
For the thing, it is nevertheless large, incomparable.
So what we see by comparing these two lists is that they overlap to a pretty large extent.
However, some interesting facts point out to look at this list or at this set of overall Twitter activities we see that Canada, Australia and Singapore are highly ranked countries.
The population of very active in overall tweeting activities, but they do not occur in the music listening activities.
So in comparison to their total number of Twitter activities, they seem to communicate to a lesser extent.
Music listening activities.
Whereas.
If we look at the music listening activity chart in here, we see that people in China, South Korea, and Venezuela tend to communicate a lot of there.
Using listening activities in comparison to their overall Twitter activities.

Compared to the predictions made by Twitter with the predictions made by last FM and we analyzed them on different scopes, so the first one is just the day-to-day matching.

All artists listening or music listening activities correspond irrespective of the time.

The overlap is between last FM's predictions and Twitters predictions.
